docs.lead_paragraph: Nathan Glazer has had more second thoughts in his lifetime than most people have had thoughts. He is the most modest (and the least tendentious) of the brilliant Jewish boys who attended City College 60 years ago and later came to be known collectively as the New York Intellectuals. The City College crowd helped chart postwar America's ideological frontier; like many of his classmates, Glazer journeyed steadily rightward for decades, from Trotskyist to social democrat to neo-conservative. But lately, Glazer has begun to adopt -- though scarcely embrace -- some strikingly liberal positions. This spring, Glazer wrote in The New Republic that without affirmative action, hardly any blacks would gain admission to top colleges; and that, he argued, would ''undermine the legitimacy of American democracy.'' Glazer seemed resigned rather than enthusiastic, but it was nonetheless a startling reversal from a scholar who two decades earlier wrote ''Affirmative Discrimination,'' a stinging critique of racial (and other) preferences. Such is Glazer's prestige, and his reputation for intellectual honesty, that in some liberal precincts his anguished turnaround has been celebrated as a portent of a conservative crack-up, at least on issues of race. Well, perhaps. But it's also possible to read in the 50-year arc of Glazer's career a terrible dashing of the hopes that liberalism itself once rested upon. In books like ''Beyond the Melting Pot,'' which he wrote with Daniel Patrick Moynihan, and in countless essays, Glazer, who for nearly 30 years has been a sociology professor at Harvard, advanced a vision of a pluralistic culture that offered a niche to each new group that came to our shores, while encouraging -- at times compelling -- assimilation into the larger society.

headline.main: Nathan Glazer Changes His Mind, Again

docs.lead_paragraph: Columbia University's School of Public Health will announce this week that the Mailman Foundation is giving it $33 million, the largest donation ever to a school of public health. The school will be named in honor of Joseph L. Mailman, a founder of the Mailman Corporation, one of the earliest conglomerates in North America. He died in 1990.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE scarcity of good new operas in the present decade -- unless something remarkable happens more than once during the next year and a half -- makes all the more striking how much was achieved in the 80's. Messiaen's only stage work, ''St. Francois d'Assise,'' was presented by the Paris Opera. La Scala in Milan produced the first three installments in Karlheinz Stockhausen's series of operas for the days of the week: ''Thursday,'' ''Saturday'' and ''Monday.'' Luciano Berio had two operas staged in quick succession: ''La Vera Storia'' and ''Un Re in Ascolto.'' So did Harrison Birtwistle, with ''The Mask of Orpheus'' and ''Yan Tan Tethera.'' John Adams's ''Nixon in China'' also made its bow. Not all of those works have entirely disappeared from the theater. ''St. Francois'' had a spectacular second production, at Salzburg in 1992, and will be revived there this summer. ''Nixon'' crops up from time to time, and so do the Berio operas: ''Un Re in Ascolto'' most recently at the Lyric Opera of Chicago in 1996. But all these pieces are more likely to go on playing in the theater of the mind, their scores heard from recordings, and the recent release on CD of ''Un Re in Ascolto'' and ''The Mask of Orpheus'' fills two important gaps.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court ruling that people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, are protected from discrimination under the Americans With Disabilities Act even if they suffer no symptoms of AIDS. The opinion, Randon Bragdon v. Sidney Abbott, was written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy and joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. A dissenting opinion was written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and joined by Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas, and Sandra Day O'Connor. FROM THE DECISION By Justice Kennedy Respondent Sidney Abbott has been infected with H.I.V. since 1986. When the incidents we recite occurred, her infection had not manifested its most serious symptoms. On Sept. 16, 1994, she went to the office of petitioner Randon Bragdon in Bangor, Me., for a dental appointment. She disclosed her H.I.V. infection on the patient registration form.

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans today unveiled a long-awaited proposal to define patients' rights and set uniform nationwide standards for health insurance, especially health maintenance organizations. The insurance industry immediately denounced the plan, saying it would increase costs for consumers. The House Republicans, who have been working behind closed doors for four months on legislation to address voters' anger at the constraints of managed health care, found themselves in the same position as President Clinton four years ago: in the cross hairs of the insurance industry.

headline.main: G.O.P. Unveils A Bill to Define Patients' Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The first time my name appeared in The New York Times linked with Dan Quayle's -- when he accused the character I played, Murphy Brown, of glamorizing out-of-wedlock pregnancy -- I decided not to reply. I had no desire to heap ridicule and scorn on the Office of the Vice President, especially when Mr. Quayle seemed to be doing a fine job of that all by himself.
